A **morning star** is a type of [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a one-handed [melee](/wiki/Melee "Melee") weapon that is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron").

The morning star is the [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") for the [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") [Trollsbane](/wiki/Trollsbane "Trollsbane").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Morning star skill](#Morning_star_skill)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

  - [6.1 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.2 notdNetHack](#notdNetHack)
  - [6.3 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

Morning stars make up about 1.2% of randomly generated weapons (on the floor, as [death drops](/wiki/Death_drop "Death drop"), or in [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop")).

In addition to random generation, general [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop") and antique weapon outlets can sell morning stars.

[Player monsters](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster"), including those on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane"), have a 3⁄290 chance (roughly 1.03%) of generating with a morning star before role replacements - the morning star has a 1⁄2 chance to be made into an artifact, which will always be Trollsbane if it has not yet been generated.

## Morning star skill

| Morning star |                                                                                                                                         |
| ------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Max          | [Role](/wiki/Role "Role")                                                                                                               |
| Basic        | - [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman"), [Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue"), [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") |
| Skilled      | * [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian"), [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")                                                             |
| Expert       | - [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest")                                                                                                       |

The morning star is the only weapon to use the **morning star** [skill](/wiki/Skill "Skill").

## Strategy

Morning stars deal passable damage to the small monsters encountered early on, but have somewhat lackluster damage against larger monsters - they are also quite heavy at 120 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum"), and are generally too rare for most characters to consider investing skill points in. Roles capable of advancing the skill usually have better long-term options readily available, such as the [battle-axe](/wiki/Battle-axe "Battle-axe") for Barbarians, the Knight's [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword") and the Rogue's stack of [daggers](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger"); the [aklys](/wiki/Aklys "Aklys") is weaker, but has very convenient ranged applications and is also available to most roles capable of using morning stars.

## History

The morning star first appears in [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Morning star (weapon)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morning_star_\(weapon\) "wikipedia:Morning star (weapon)")***

A morning star is any of several medieval club-like weapons consisting of a wooden shaft and an attached iron ball adorned with one or more spikes, designed for use as a bludgeon to wound or kill enemies. The morning star first came into widespread use around the beginning of the 14th century, particularly in Germany where it was known as *Morgenstern*. Morning stars were used by both infantry and cavalry, with the ones used by horsemen the horseman's weapon had a shorter shaft. Many surviving morning stars were two-handed and typically six feet in length if not longer.

Morning stars are often conflated with [maces](/wiki/Mace "Mace"), which use flanges or knobs as opposed to spiked balls and were entirely metallic, as well as military [flails](/wiki/Flail "Flail"), which typically consist of an iron-shod wooden bar joined to a shift by chain (with ball-and-chain flails seemingly quite uncommon). Three different types of morning star have been found: the well-crafted military type, made by expert weapon-smiths and used by professional soldiers; a second, much simpler type, hand-cut from wood by peasant militia men and fitted with spikes by a local blacksmith; and a third, decorative metallic type with a shorter shaft. The "simple" morning star usually had a combined shaft and head, sometimes reinforced at the top with an iron band.

## Variants

Variants with [object material](/wiki/Object_material "Object material") systems may make morning stars somewhat more appealing if discovered early on with a lighter material. Some variants add more weapons that use the morning star skill.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), the morning star deals 2d6 damage to small monsters and 1d8+1 to large monsters, and its weight is reduced to 80 aum.

[Iris](/wiki/Spirits_\(dNetHack\)#Iris.2C_Friend_from_Afar "Spirits (dNetHack)") is a [spirit](/wiki/Spirits_\(dNetHack\) "Spirits (dNetHack)") that grants skill in morning stars while bound.

There are two artifact new morning stars, in addition to [Trollsbane](/wiki/Trollsbane "Trollsbane"):

- [Bloodletter](/wiki/Bloodletter "Bloodletter") is an unaligned artifact that has several blood-related effects.
- [The Ruinous Descent of Stars](/wiki/The_Ruinous_Descent_of_Stars "The Ruinous Descent of Stars") is a chaotic [intelligent artifact](/wiki/Intelligent_artifact "Intelligent artifact") that favors [drow](/wiki/Drow_\(starting_race\) "Drow (starting race)") and is made of [silvered](/wiki/Silver "Silver") [metal](/wiki/Metal "Metal"), and acts as the chaotic [crowning](/wiki/Crowning "Crowning") gift for hedrow [Nobles](/wiki/Noble "Noble") and drow [Healers](/wiki/Healer "Healer").

### notdNetHack

In [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), in addition to dNetHack details, Iris generates with a +7 morning star that has the [psionic](/index.php?title=Psionic\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Psionic (page does not exist)") [object property](/wiki/Object_property "Object property") when summoned by an [Illithanachronounbinder](/wiki/Illithanachronounbinder "Illithanachronounbinder").

### EvilHack

[EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") merges the morning star skill into the [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace") skill and adds the [orcish morning star](/wiki/Orcish_morning_star "Orcish morning star"), an [orcish](/wiki/Orcish "Orcish") variant of the weapon.

[Dwarven](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster") [sergeants](/wiki/Sergeant "Sergeant") have a 1⁄2 chance of generating with a morning star, and [gnolls](/wiki/Gnoll_\(EvilHack\) "Gnoll (EvilHack)"), [gnoll hunters](/wiki/Gnoll_hunter "Gnoll hunter") and [flinds](/wiki/Flind_\(EvilHack\) "Flind (EvilHack)") have a 2⁄3 chance of generating with one. The [Paladin](/wiki/Paladin_\(monster\) "Paladin (monster)") is always generated with a morning star of an enchantment between +3 and +5; [Lucifer](/wiki/Lucifer "Lucifer") is always generated with a morning star that has the fire [object property](/wiki/Object_property "Object property").

A morning star can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining a dagger and a mace. Morning stars can be used to create a couple of items:

- A morning star can be combined with a mace to create a flail.
- A morning star can be combined with [barding](/wiki/Barding_\(item\) "Barding (item)") to make [spiked barding](/wiki/Spiked_barding "Spiked barding").

## Encyclopedia entry

The morning star was a medieval weapon resembling a mace, but  
with a large spike on the end and smaller spikes around the  
circumference. It was also known as the goedendag (from the  
Dutch word for "good day") and the holy water sprinkler (from  
its resemblance to the aspergillum sometimes used in the  
Catholic Mass). It was used by both cavalry and infantry;  
the horseman's weapon typically had a shorter haft than the  
footman's, which might be up to six feet long. It came into  
use in the beginning of the 14th century.  
The name "morning star" is often erroneously applied to the  
military flail (also known as the therscol), a similar weapon,  
but with the head attached by a short chain.

\[ Dictionary of Medieval Knighthood and Chivalry,  
 by Bradford Broughton ]
